	I was thinking more along the lines of a weekly build type of
process, where everyone puts their updated code into a central location and
the buildmaster compiles and tests everything. I can easily envision a case
where someone either forgets to test their code or checks in the wrong code.
If a suite of tests was represented within a single test, you would get a
single confusing error rather than a flurry of errors which might give you a
better idea of what's going on. 

	Yes, it would be nice if we were all in an agile/extreme world where
everyone was testing their code multiple times a day and builds were a daily
occurrence, but some of us are in traditional with the "fragile" way of
doing things and are doing the best we can ;-)

	-tim

If you run your test at regular intervals (e.g. hourly) then isolating
failures shouldn't be a problem.  Of course if your system is massive then a
full system test is out the question, but if you break your tests into
suites then you can run the suites on the section that you have being
working on.  Then run the rest of the tests overnight.

JUnit does tell you which test failed, so isolating the test shouldn't be a
problem and if your test is only testing one method than it shouldn't be a
problem either, because your method is nice and simple right?  Unless you
have inherited some legacy stuff and have only started your unit testing in
the middle of your project.  Also why would the build take so long.  You
only have to re-build the class you altered don't you?

>And that JUnit fail after one test fails, so what?  You want all tests to
>pass so if one fails, find it, fix your code, and go again.

This can be a big problem in large systems that take minutes (or longer) to
compile and test. It's nice to get a complete list of failures so that you
can attempt to fix as many as possible before having to dive into the build
process again...

-tim
